title: Can I file for bankruptcy to clear my hospital bill debt?
question: Hello,
answers:
11 U.S.C. § 523(a)(9) excludes from bankruptcy discharge any debt for death or personal injury caused by the debtor’s operation of a motor vehicle, vessel, or aircraft if such operation was unlawful because the debtor was intoxicated from using alcohol, a drug, or another substance.

Here the question becomes whether the statute means any debt due to injury to any person (including yourself) or if it only refers to debt due to injury to someone else. I am sure there is a case on point, but you'll need to talk to a Bankruptcy attorney to be sure.

Yes, you can file for relief under the bankruptcy code and your medical bills should be discharged. If you owe the power company for damage to the power poll, that would not be discharged in a chapter 7, but could be discharged in a chapter 13.

The best way to answer your question and determine if which bankruptcy chapter would be the best option for you is to take advantage of a free initial consultation with an experienced bankruptcy attorney that handles chapter 7 and chapter 13 cases even if you think you need to file under chapter 7. Become educated on all the issues involved and related to your current economic situation, find out the advantages and disadvantages for filing under each chapter and use an attorney that can help you make the right for you. Most bankruptcy attorneys will meet with you at no charge for the initial appointment. You can use the Avvo "Find a Lawyer" link at the top of this page to search for an attorney. You can look at each attorney’s profile to see what type of cases they handle and how Avvo ranks them.
One can discharge their own medical debt in a bankruptcy. The next questions falls on whether you would file under Chapter 7 versus Chapter 13.
